The cardinal number of a type

name: Cardinal.mk
docString: The cardinal number of a type

For all natural numbers n, the first binary digit of n, represented as `bit1 n` in Lean, is non-zero. Equivalently, the binary representation of a natural number has an odd number of 1's.

name: Nat.bit1_ne_zero
docString: For all natural numbers n, the first binary digit of n, represented as `bit1 n` in Lean, is non-zero. Equivalently, the binary representation of a natural number has an odd number of 1's.

This theorem states that for any natural number 'n', the norm (or absolute value) of 'n' when it is coerced (or converted) into a real number is equal to 'n' itself as a real number. Essentially, this means that the absolute value of any natural number is just the number itself when both are considered as real numbers.

name: Real.norm_coe_nat
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number 'n', the norm (or absolute value) of 'n' when it is coerced (or converted) into a real number is equal to 'n' itself as a real number. Essentially, this means that the absolute value of any natural number is just the number itself when both are considered as real numbers.

The underlying natural number

name: PNat.val
docString: The underlying natural number

Every natural number can be expressed as an even number (the sum of two identical numbers) or an odd number (2 times an integer plus 1).

name: Nat.even_or_odd
docString: Every natural number can be expressed as an even number (the sum of two identical numbers) or an odd number (2 times an integer plus 1).

This theorem states that for every natural number `n`, `n` is either equal to zero or greater than zero. In other words, it asserts that any natural number is either zero or a positive integer. This is a fundamental property of natural numbers in the standard mathematical system.

name: Nat.eq_zero_or_pos
docString: This theorem states that for every natural number `n`, `n` is either equal to zero or greater than zero. In other words, it asserts that any natural number is either zero or a positive integer. This is a fundamental property of natural numbers in the standard mathematical system.

A product of finite numbers is still finite

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_1} {R : Type u_8} [inst : CommMonoidWithZero R] [inst_1 : NoZeroDivisors R] [inst_2 : Nontrivial R]
  [inst_3 : DecidableEq R] [inst_4 : LT R] {s : Finset ι} {f : ι → WithTop R},
  (∀ i ∈ s, f i ≠ ⊤) → (Finset.prod s fun i => f i) < ⊤
name: WithTop.prod_lt_top
docString: A product of finite numbers is still finite

An arrow ending in the zero object is zero

docString: An arrow ending in the zero object is zero

A sum of numbers is infinite iff one of them is infinite

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_1} {M : Type u_4} [inst : AddCommMonoid M] {s : Finset ι} {f : ι → WithTop M},
  (Finset.sum s fun i => f i) = ⊤ ↔ ∃ i ∈ s, f i = ⊤
name: WithTop.sum_eq_top_iff
docString: A sum of numbers is infinite iff one of them is infinite
